qas.question: Is active TB difficult or easy to diagnose by patients' symptoms alone?
If a patient has some symptoms associated with TB, after what time period should tuberculosis be diagnostically considered?
What part of the body would be X-rayed to check for TB?
What sign of TB infection would a lab be looking for in a sputum culture?
Along with interferon-y release essays, what other tests aren't useful in TB diagnosis in developing countries?
What is usually diagnosed using just signs and symptoms?
How long do symptoms in someone who is immunosuppressed last?
What kind of cultures test for HIV?

plausible_answers.text: Interferon-γ release assays and tuberculin skin tests

qas.question: What kind of tests are common in developing countries?
What type of bacilli do interferon-y release assays look for?

context: Diagnosing <b5_0>active tuberculosis<b5_0/> based only on signs and symptoms is <a0_0>difficult<a0_0/>, as is diagnosing the disease in those who are immunosuppressed. A diagnosis of TB should, however, be considered in those with signs of lung disease or constitutional symptoms lasting <b6_0>longer than <a1_0>two weeks<b6_0/><a1_0/>. A <a2_0>chest<a2_0/> X-ray and <b7_0>multiple sputum<b7_0/> cultures for <a3_0><b9_0>acid-fast<b9_0/> bacilli<a3_0/> are typically part of the initial evaluation. <b8_0>Interferon-γ release assays and <a4_0>tuberculin skin tests<b8_0/><a4_0/> are of little use in the developing world. IGRA have similar limitations in those with HIV.
